qas.question: What part of the brain most strongly differentiates mammals from other vertebrates?
The three-layered structure covering the cerebrum in non-mammals is known as what?
Mammals have a pallium that involved into what?
The hippocampus and amygdala are ares inside what structure?

context: Size, however, is not the only difference: there are also substantial differences in shape. The hindbrain and midbrain of mammals are generally similar to those of other vertebrates, but dramatic differences appear in the forebrain, which is greatly enlarged and also altered in structure. <a0_0>The cerebral cortex<a0_0/> is the part of the brain that most strongly distinguishes mammals. In non-mammalian vertebrates, the surface of the cerebrum is lined with a comparatively simple three-layered structure called the <a1_0>pallium<a1_0/>. In mammals, the pallium evolves into a complex six-layered structure called <a2_0>neocortex or isocortex<a2_0/>. Several areas at the edge of the <a3_0>neocortex<a3_0/>, including the hippocampus and amygdala, are also much more extensively developed in mammals than in other vertebrates.
